subject: Re: [junit] A new open source testing framework - Jetif
msgSnippet: ... This is entirely untrue. See Scott Stirling s good work in Chapter 5 of _JUnit Recipes_. ... You seem to frame this like a downside. Frameworks /should/ be
messageBody:
wangtlcn wrote:

> As we know, JUnit is a great regression testing framework,
> while you have to hard code all test data because its
> "no-param, no-return" design. You have to recompile your code
> when you want to change the test data.

This is entirely untrue. See Scott Stirling's good work in Chapter 5 of
_JUnit Recipes_.

> And another issue is
> there are some features desired by developers while not
> included in the framework, you have to use extra extensions
> to do something such as logging, result recording...

You seem to frame this like a downside. Frameworks /should/ be light and
supplemented by extension. That's what a good framework is; and not a
suite of tools that do everything. That's a /platform/.

> To solve these problems, I create a new testing framework
> which separate test code and data, it's called "Jetif".
> The Jetif is designed for the purpose that to provides a
> powerful and flexiable testing framework with many of
> features which developers desired.
>
> There is a short article to compare Jetif and JUnit+JTestCase:
> http://jetif.sourceforge.net/comparison.html
>
> Please visit http://sourceforge.net/projects/jetif/
> for more information.

It looks like a good project; but I'd prefer you didn't malign JUnit
with false statements.

Q: Why not extend JUnit with the very best data-driven suite mechanism
on the planet? The market would love that.

Take care.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
